sections.heading: protest as evidence of dishonor; bill of exchange or promissory note
sections.text: The usual protest by a notary public, without proof of his signature or notarial seal, is evidence of the dishonor and notice of a bill of exchange or promissory note.SourceR.S.1867, Code § 349, p. 452;R.S.1913, § 7905;C.S.1922, §

25-1213.Notarial protest as evidence of dishonor; bill of exchange or promissory note.

The usual protest by a notary public, without proof of his signature or notarial seal, is evidence of the dishonor and notice of a bill of exchange or promissory note.

SourceR.S.1867, Code § 349, p. 452;R.S.1913, § 7905;C.S.1922, § 8847;C.S.1929, § 20-1213;R.S.1943, § 25-1213.

Annotations

Certificate of notary is evidence of notice as well as protest. Williams v. Parks, 63 Neb. 747, 89 N.W. 395 (1902).
